DOC.brief_summary: Can risedronate given once weekly for 6 months prevent periprosthetic bone loss after uncemented total hip arthroplasty?
DOC.brief_title: Can Risedronate Prevent Periprosthetic Bone Loss After Total Hip Arthroplasty
DOC.detailed_description: Periprosthetic bone loss after total hip arthroplasty is the main factor in limiting the longevity of implants used for treatment of osteoarthritis. Bone loss leads to implant destabilization. Bisphosphonates, given for approximately 6 months after THA man prevent this bone loss and lead to longer implant fixation and lower incidence of aseptic prosthesis loosening. We perform a clinical trial with risedronate to investigate if we can influence periprosthetic bone loss around a uncemented femoral stem.
DOC.criteria: Patients on the waiting list for a total hip arthroplasty Primary osteoarthritis Osteoarthritis secondary to congenital dislocation of the hip Rheumatoid arthritis Bisphosphonate treatment Osteomalacia Hypocalcemia Previous surgery of the affected hip
